reporting-org.narrative: The federal government of the United States

title.narrative: Improving the conservation status of the remaining Macaw populations in Northeastern Paraguay

description.narrative: Conserve biodiversity and manage natural resources in ways that maintain their long-term viability and preserve their potential to meet the needs of present and future generations. Activities include combating illegal and corrupt exploitation of natural resources and the control of invasive species. Programs in this element should be integrated with the Agriculture Area under Economic Growth and Conflict Mitigation and Reconciliation Area under the Peace and Security Category, when applicable and appropriate.

This award strives to conserve biodiversity and manage natural resources in ways that maintain their long-term viability and preserve their potential to meet the needs of present and future generations. Activities include combating illegal and corrupt exploitation of natural resources and the control of invasive species. This includes Illegal wildlife trade is a multi-billion-dollar activity and wild birds (especially parrots and macaws, family Psittacidae) are currently threatened with extinction due to the high numbers of individuals involved in domestic and international wildlife trafficking annually. Of the 25 species of parrots recorded in Paraguay, eight are of conservation concern, including six species of concern at the global level, all of which are threatened by illegal pet trade. In fact, data indicates that in Paraguay there are more macaws in captivity than there are in the wild indicating that viable breeding couples in the wild are risk. This project will reduce poaching and trade of Psittacidae in Paraguay, with a specific focus on the Hyacinth Macaw, Blue-and-Yellow Macaw Green-winged Macaw, Blue-winged Macaw and the Yellow-faced Amazon. Specific objectives include assessing Psittacidae population status and assisting local communities to prevent wildlife trade; creating poach-free areas to promote population recovery; conducting national and local public awareness programs on the impact of poaching and the illegal wildlife trade of parrot/macaws; and support law enforcement agents and existing enforcement measures..

participating-org.narrative: The federal government of the United States

participating-org.usg:office-name: Fish and Wildlife Service/Office of International Affairs

owner-org.narrative: The federal government of the United States

description.narrative: The Government of Paraguay is making significant advances in fighting corruption and impunity and eradicating extreme poverty. Encouraged by a recently approved Freedom of Information Law and widely available public notices, citizens are denouncing irregularities and sending a clear message that corruption will not be tolerated. Although high levels of income inequality remain, Paraguayan government programs are producing positive results in reducing poverty and in countering illicit activities in the northern region. U.S. assistance programs add momentum to these positive developments, helping Paraguay strengthen its democratic institutions and supporting more equitable and environmentally sustainable economic growth.
